sub_title: Research Software Engineer| HDip in Science in Computing | Software Engineering | Python | R | SQL | Linux | Agile | Java | Distributed Systems | HTML/Javascript | Polyglot
summary:
I started my career as a multidisciplinary scientist with ambitions towards statistical modelling and data science in environmental and medical domains. 

Some of the skills are listed below:
• OS: *nix, Windows
• LaTeX, R, Java, Python,  Web Design (html, JavaScript, jQuery),  vim, bash, QGIS, databases, git, visualisation software, Tensorflow, Docker, CI/CD
• Hands-on experience of data integration, processing and statistical analysis
• Variety of machine learning and statistical techniques: 
imbalanced data, survival analysis, spatial statistics, generalised linear geostatistical modelling, zero-inflation, multivariate data analysis, time series, panel data, discrete choice, multiple regression models, dimensionality reduction (PCA, DFA), clustering and classification (boosting regression trees, random forest, logistic regression, SVM), GLMM, GAM, Hidden-Markov Models and deep neural networks (CNN, RNN, NLP).

For further information on my research activity please refer to my profile on Research Gate  https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Olga-Lyashevska

projects.title: Dynamic factor analysis to investigate coherency in growth patterns across various fish species
projects.description:
Problem statement: Do fish species display synchronous changes in growth and are these
changes indicative of a common response to broad scale environmental drivers?
Fish growth rates fluctuate in response to environmental conditions (primarily food abundance
and temperature) and are influenced by intra and interspecific competition and by size-selective
effects of fishing. Modelling temporal growth patterns across multiple fish species can help to
disentangle the various drivers of change and to detect synchronous responses to broad scale
ecosystem change.
This study uses dynamic factor analysis to determine the extent to which weight-at-age time
series display synchronous changes across multiple pelagic (herring, mackerel, blue-whiting) and
demersal (cod, haddock, plaice, sole) fish species in the Northeast Atlantic. Generalised additive
mixed models are fit to the data for each species with age modelled as a spline and year-of-birth
and year-of-capture as random effects. Extracted random effects and their variance-covariance
matrices for each year are then modelled using dynamic factor analysis to identify common
trends. Relationships between the resultant trends and various potential drivers are examined.
Drivers of change examined include: estimates of recruitment from the annual stock assessments
to account for density-dependent changes in size at the species level; and the influence of density-
independent environmental effects (e.g. temperature, zooplankton abundance, wind patterns
and climatic indices)is also be examined. The possible impacts of the observed trends on
productivity and ecosystem resilience are discussed.

profile_positions.description:
Application of statistical, analytical  and computational methods to research questions in ecological and biomedical domain.

Some of the projects include:
- Harbour Porpoise statistical review and power analysis (Principal Investigator)
- PhD project: Machine Learning assisted detection and prediction of climate change related anomalous events in complex marine systems (Project Coordinator)
- PhD project: Predicting clinical outcomes for treated stroke cases using Deep Learning (Project Coordinator)
-  Biological Tools to Measure the Impact of Flow on Ecology in Irish Rivers (Project Participant)
-  Framework for characterising oligotrophic lakes using practical methods and assessment tools (Project Participant)

profile_positions.title: Guest Researcher at Soil Physics and Land Use

profile_positions.description:
Project title: Quantifying biodiversity for valuation.
Abstract: Biodiversity is a multi-dimensional and complex concept with a rather loose definition. To construct a more substantial definition of biodiversity, a theoretical argument aiming to link biodiversity and functional (meaningful) information needs to be developed. A working hypothesis is that biodiversity is a measure of the total difference within a biological system, which can be summarised in terms of the system’s total information content, of which functional information is a subset. Since functional information has systematic patterns, it coincides with the scientific meaning of biological complexity, thus providing the foundation of value in biodiversity. The theory presented sets the goal of estimating biological complexity from the potentially valuable information derived from empirical biodiversity metric data (ecological measures).
To achieve this, the ecological properties of a system were translated into a simply defined single valued property. This led to a conclusion that if there exists a systematic relationship among empirical biodiversity metrics, then there must be a unifying property underlying intrinsic value of biodiversity. Then, an advantage of a representation of biodiversity as information was demonstrated by comparing it with the most commonly used metric – species richness. It was shown that species richness missed a large proportion of diversity, emphasising the importance of additional ecological properties (e.g. functional traits, presence, and abundances in communities, as well as phylogenetic information). Finally, by providing intellectual foundations and developing an analytical tool for biodiversity quantification, this study sets the goal for further research. An advantage of the approach in this study to economic valuation is that value is based on real, measurable, and intrinsic properties of systems.
